P-Quotients of L-presented groups
The nilpotent quotient algorithm for finitely L-presented groups and the p-quotient algorithm for finitely presented group readily generalize to an algorithm for computing a polycyclic presentation for the p-quotient of a L-presented group.
returns a polycyclic presentation for the p-class-c quotient g/\phi_{c+1}(g) of the L-presented group g if c is specified. If c is not given, this method attempts to compute the largest p-quotient of g and will terminate only if g has such a largest p-quotient.
The following example computes the 2-class-5 quotient of the Grigorchuk group.
gap> G:=ExamplesOfLPresentations( 1 );; gap> H:=NqPQuotient( G, 2, 5 ); Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2 ] gap> pcs := PCentralSeries( H ); [ Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2 ], Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2 ], Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2, 2, 2 ], Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2 ], Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2 ], Pcp-group with orders [ ] ] gap> List( [1..Length(pcs)-1], x -> AbelianInvariants( pcs[x]/pcs[x+1] ) ); [ [ 2, 2, 2 ], [ 2, 2 ], [ 2, 2 ], [ 2 ], [ 2, 2 ] ]
This method returns an epimorphism from the L-presented group g onto a p-quotient. If the optional argument c is given, the epimorphism is onto the maximal class-c quotient g//\phi_{c+1}(g). If no second argument is given, this method attempts to compute an epimorphism onto the largest p-quotient of g. If g does not have a largest p-quotient, this method will not terminate.
The following example computes an epimorphism from the Grigorchuk group onto its 2-class-5 quotients.
gap> G:=ExamplesOfLPresentations( 1 ); <invariant LpGroup of size infinity on the generators [ a, b, c, d ]> gap> epi := NqEpimorphismPQuotient( G, 2, 5 ); [ a, b, c, d ] -> [ g1, g2*g3, g2, g3 ] gap> H := Image(epi); Pcp-group with orders [ 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2 ] gap> PClassPGroup( H ); 5
